abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Constitutional heterozygous pathogenic variants in the exonuclease domain of <jats:italic>POLE</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>POLD1</jats:italic>, which affect the proofreading activity of the corresponding polymerases, cause a cancer predisposition syndrome characterized by increased risk of gastrointestinal polyposis, colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer and other tumor types. The generally accepted explanation for the connection between the disruption of the proofreading activity of polymerases epsilon and delta and cancer development is through an increase in the somatic mutation rate. Here we studied an extended family with multiple members heterozygous for the pathogenic <jats:italic>POLD1</jats:italic> variant c.1421T>C p.(Leu474Pro), which segregates with the polyposis and cancer phenotypes. Through the analysis of mutational patterns of patient-derived fibroblasts colonies and de novo mutations obtained by parent-offspring comparisons, we concluded that heterozygous <jats:italic>POLD1</jats:italic> L474P just subtly increases the somatic and germline mutation burden. In contrast, tumors developed in individuals with a heterozygous mutation in the exonuclease domain of <jats:italic>POLD1</jats:italic>, including L474P, have an extremely high mutation rate (>100 mut/Mb) associated with signature SBS10d. We solved this contradiction through the observation that tumorigenesis involves somatic inactivation of the wildtype <jats:italic>POLD1</jats:italic> allele. These results imply that exonuclease deficiency of polymerase delta has a recessive effect on mutation rate.</jats:p>
